awd_titl_txt: Nano-spectroscopic imaging and control of coupled dynamics in local molecular environments
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Raschke of the University of Colorado, Boulder, plans to develop a series of close-up ("near field") spectroscopic and imaging techniques to study the behavior of molecules and how they interact with their environment. He and his group use a combination of creative approaches to measure fast events (i.e. at the femtosecond time scale) at high resolution (i.e. with nanometer spatial resolution). The experiment outcomes provide information about different quantum states of a molecule, which will help to understand a molecule's properties and function at the most elemental level. The knowledge will eventually help to understand and then make new materials as catalysts, electronics, and other photonic materials. This interdisciplinary project provides broad research training for graduate and undergraduate students in Professor Raschke's lab.  They will also have the opportunity to participate in community outreach and experience technology transfer to industry.  

In order to gain the spectroscopic access into the nano- to molecular length scales and their dynamics, a combination of novel near-field optical scanning probe microscopy modalities is developed and applied. In nonlinear and ultrafast nano-imaging using femtosecond four-wave mixing and photo-current spectroscopy the coupled electronic and vibrational quantum dynamics is studied in quantum dots, quantum plasmonic, and strongly coupled plasmon-exciton systems, using femtosecond adiabatic nano-focusing. In variable temperature single molecule nano-Raman spectroscopy, with nano-mechanical tip-sample probing, and tunneling transport conditions, in polyaromatic hydrocarbons and self-assembled monolayer, spectra diffusion, intramolecular vibrational energy redistribution, orientational dynamics, and plasmon hot-electron processes are investigated. This research is advancing basic science while being technology enabling simultaneously providing for the understanding of molecular materials as chemical nano-imaging as the enabling technique is refined. With its interdisciplinary nature this project provides for broad research training for graduate and undergraduate students including their participation in community outreach and technology transfer to industry.

por.por_cntn:
Tip-enhanced near-field imaging has become an established part of the rapidly growing portfolio of microscopy modalities that uniquely provide nanometer spatially resolved spectroscopic imaging of molecular and quantum materials. The traditional emphasis in the development of these methods has been in the judicious choice of near-field tip-sample coupling and optical excitation to only minimally interfere with the electronic or vibrational quantum states of the material in order to infer the intrinsic material properties. However, in this project we broke with this traditional paradigm. Through extreme tip-induced optical mode confinement at the tip apex or nano-focused femtosecond light pulses, we deliberately modify the material and optical response in ways to produce from new light-matter hybrid states to enhanced optical nonlinearities.

As a particular highlight of this project, we established the new technique of tip-enhanced strong coupling (TESC). Here, the plasmonic tip when in close proximity to a mirror substrate forms a cavity with deep sub-diffraction limited mode volume. The resulting orders of magnitude enhanced light-matter coupling strength compared to conventional cavities gives rise to hybrid plasmon-exciton states. In proof-of-concept experiments in TESC with this qualitatively new approach of compelling conceptual simplicity, we demonstrated strong coupling with single quantum dots. With pico-cavity scanning, and sub-nanometer mode volume tuning, we control the coupling strength and reversibly address single quantum states. This work laid the foundation as a universal approach to induce, probe, and control single-emitter hybrid quantum states for applications to control quantum dynamics, photochemical pathways, or quantum transduction even at room temperature.

In another avenue, we use ultrashort light pulses of few-femtosecond duration to induce nanolocalized coherent nonlinear four-wave mixing. Besides its use for coherent spatio-temporal nano-imaging, we discovered a new mechanism in nonlinear optics where the strong optical gradient fields at the apex can drive conventionally symmetry-forbidden nonlinear optical processes. This results in an increase in nonlinear conversion efficiency inversely proportional to the apex radius. This enhancement of nonlinear frequency conversion efficiency defines a new regime of nonlinear nano-optics with the potential to overcome the conventional limit of a decrease in nonlinear response with decreasing sample volume.

With its interdisciplinary nature the project provided for a broad training environment for undergraduate and graduate students, and postdocs. They all advanced or established their independent career in research and education in imaging and laser science in academia or industry closely related to the subject of this grant. This includes the broad dissemination of optical nano-imaging and -spectroscopy techniques we developed through this grant to industry collaborators and national lab user facilities, notably the development of cryogen-free closed cycle scanning probe microscopy, and new optical platforms for tip-enhanced imaging and spectroscopy.

In summary the project broadly advanced molecular and nano-materials imaging providing increasingly deeper insight into the elementary processes underlying functional materials at the level of the elementary building blocks and quantum states helping to establish the targeted design of the next generation of electrochemical, photonic, electronic, and energy technologies.
